 Murder laws are not based on faith
 Our democracy is based on the realization of our founders, that no evidence supports the claim (made by such people as King George III) that some people are naturally born with more inherent authority than other people. Because of the lack of evidence supporting such a claim, we must assume no special authority for anyone, and by default assume that all people are created with the same inherent authorities - defined in our constitution as "rights". This reality-based idea is the basis for the passage of "murder" laws that prevent you from assuming the authority to rob from me my right to life.
 
 Also, there's a difference between laws informed by faith, and laws based on faith. In the abortion issue, you are making an assertion about reality that is unproven, and then you are making a law based on that assertion of faith. 
 
 
 
2) To completely forbid religious faith from effecting the law would necessitate that we prohibit anyone who has any religious faith from voting.

 
 Absolutely not. We all have beliefs that are religious in nature. We're all expected to vote our conscience. Faith-based ideas can, and do, become constitutionally valid laws. Likewise, laws informed by none-sense can, and do, get passed by the will of the majority all the time. It only becomes a problem when those laws conflict with constitutionally protected civil liberties. 
 
 
1) You are of the opinion that a zygote is not a person. This is far from conclusive.

 
 The burden of proof is upon you. 
 
 
 
 
2) We restrict civil liberties all the time.

 
 Not without reason and constitutional justification. Usually this justification happens when the rights of one person come into conflict with the rights of another.
 
 What's the legal basis for limiting a person's right to receive a proven-to-be-safe medical procedure?
 
 If the basis is that a ferilized egg is a person, then you need to show evidence for that claim.
